awd_titl_txt: CRII: CPS: Bilateral Adaptation Between Models for Human-Perceived Safety/Comfort and Autonomous Driving Controllers
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses perceived safety within the context of autonomous driving. Self-driving cars have great potential to transform our transportation system, but their technical safety does not necessarily indicate how a human will perceive the safety of autonomous driving, especially if the driving style of the passenger is less aggressive than that of the self-driving car. The goal of this research is to change the car's controller when a human shows discomfort with respect to safety. The approach is to measure physical data from passengers in simulators and in real cars, compare these to expected levels of comfort, and update the controllers using novel algorithms. The project's results will improve user acceptance of autonomous vehicles, as well as produce new curriculum and outreach programs related to autonomous driving. 

The goal of the project is to understand human perceived safety and comfort in autonomous driving and examine and bilaterally adapt the interactions between humans and autonomous vehicles in order to enhance the human perception (i.e., perceived safety and comfort) while simultaneously enhancing the vehicle performance (i.e., technical driving safety and comfort). In particular, the proposed research will (a) understand the factors affecting the human perceived safety and comfort and investigate how to quantify human perceived safety and comfort using physiological signals, (b) investigate general human and autonomous driving models and online bilateral adaptation strategies to improve the driving safety and comfort, and (c) evaluate the research outcomes using both simulated and real autonomous vehicles. The research will contribute to improving the safety and comfort of autonomous driving and is scalable to other human-autonomy interaction contexts as well.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Human perceived safety/comfort is very critical to the user acceptance of autonomous vehicles and their deployment in the real world. Despite tremendous efforts in autonomous driving research and development, the perceived safety/comfort of humans in autonomous vehicle has not been well understood. The goal of this project is to investigate human perceived safety/comfort in autonomous vehicles by experimental human studies and develop models and methodologies to quantify and improve human safety/comfort in autonomous vehicles.

The project has completed autonomous driving empirical studies and collected data to understand the factors which affect human perceived safety and comfort in autonomous driving. Based on the collected data, it has created a computational comfort model to quantify human perceived safety/comfort in autonomous vehicles based on their physiological data. It has also created a novel Inverse Model Predictive Control (IMPC) approach to analytically model the human driving behaviors which can achieve better accuracy and scalability. Based on the developed models, the project has developed a bilateral adaptation approach to adapt the automated driving controllers according to human preferences and also adapt human expectations on automated driving by incorporating safety and efficiency constraints with intuitive warning feedbacks. The research approaches have been evaluated and validated by human-in-the-loop autonomous driving experiments.

The project outcomes can help improve the user acceptance of autonomous vehicles by discovering factors affecting human perception on autonomous vehicles and designing adaption strategies of autonomous driving to improve the human perception and acceptance. The project has trained multiple graduate and undergraduate students in research with the outcomes of one Ph.D. dissertation and ten peer-reviewed publications. The vehicle autonomy work from this project has also helped to develop a K-12 summer camp. The research, course development and summer camp have involved students from graduate, undergraduate, to K-12 levels including female and underrepresented students and train them to engage in learning and practice of autonomous driving technologies. The research outcomes of the project have been disseminated to both academia and industry by publications, presentations, guest lectures, meetings, tours, and shared resources.
